author: daniellehrner
content:
I would argue that this is even worse. Because the users can make delegate calls to any number of smart contracts, so you will eventually have storage collisions. E.g. smart contract A is writing to slot 0 and smart contract B is reading from it, but is expecting a completely different value. It could also be a problem in the future, because should we eventually have a way of upgrading a EOA to a smart contract wallet the storage of the EOA might contain random values from previous delegate calls, which might cause problems.

I like that 5806 is simple and would solve some of the UX issues like batching. But I think the tradeoffs in DX and inconsistencies how smart contracts are executed are too big.

author: matt.nelson
content: how does the `value` mechanic work with a sponsored TX in this case? The value could be set to 0 in the `authcall` and the invoker pays gas based on commitment/contract logic?

author: lightclient
content: So the invoker is always paying for the gas. `value` really just unlocks ether which might be sitting in the EOAs account. There are a lot of reasons an EOA might want to send ether via an invoker i) they have setup specific access controls which allows them to spend a small amt of ether from a hot wallet ii) they are doing a multi-tx operation which requires sending value iiI) they lost their key and want to recover their ether, and on.
